{{-d '{ "links": { "avatar": { "href": "<avatar_url>" } } }'}}
fields.summary: Update Repository Icon via API

fields.description: The new source browser libraries don't look like they have support for elixer.  If you switch to the old source browser, those libraries render and syntax highlight elixer files properly.
fields.summary: New version of source browser does not properly syntax highlight elixer-lang files.

fields.description:
Hi, I'm not sure if this is an actual bug or not but here are the details of the use case:

I have two identical branches (same commits, same head):

first: bugfix/Task_name-<taskid>

second: bugfix/Task_name-taskid

**notice the angle brackets in the name of the first one.\\
**

When trying to create a PR from the first one to another branch (master in this case), I see a loading spinner at the bottom (diff/commits table) that keeps looping and the background entries for commits are greyed out. See screenshot:\\
!1814549370-Screen%20Shot%202018-03-28%20at%2019.12.44.png|thumbnail!\\
I also see that there is a js type error _Uncaught TypeError: t.createDocumentFragment is not a function_ that's not present when other branches are selected on the create PR page. There's also a screenshot of that below.\\
!1199379036-Screen%20Shot%202018-03-28%20at%2019.16.23.png|thumbnail!

When trying to create a PR from the second one, there are no problems whatsoever.

I've tried normal things like hard refreshes, recreating the branch and trying again, forking the same branch with different names, etc.

Web browser used: Google Chrome\\
Version 65.0.3325.181 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Os used: macOS High Sierra Version 10.13.3

I'm not looking for a solution or a workaround since I can just rename my branch and continue working, but I  just thought this bug was worth mentioning here.
fields.summary: Can't create pull request with angle brackets in branch name

fields.description:
Typing the @ symbol is necessary sometimes separate from the context of an @mention (let's see if that has ATmention instead of a username)

I've noticed that using the escape key seems to remove the mention link (blue link text turns black) but upon posting it will still render.

See attached gif
fields.summary: @mention still rendered after using Escape key

fields.description:
*Summary*

If you hover the mouse to the date updated in the Pull request in Safari, it will not show the exact timestamp and shows the "NaN undefined Nan" message instead.

*Steps to Reproduce*

# Create a pull request
# Mouse-over the relative time of the pull request

*Expected Results*

It will display the exact timestamp in the form of "9 March 2018 21:52"

*Actual Results*

It will display "NaN undefined NaN" instead.

*Notes*\\
Not reproducible with other browsers such as Google Chrome and Firefox.

*Workaround*\\
Use a different browser.
fields.summary: Pull Request mouse-over date displays "NaN undefined NaN" in Safari
Swagger: "size" field on "repository" type needs to be int64

fields.description:
When deploying to Bitbucket downloads it would be very useful to create folders, eg. for different build version. See my question here: https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/Is-it-possible-to-add-folders-when-deploying-to-Bitbucket/qaq-p/752799#U760525

The feature could be very useful if you want to upload the artifact and a log file to Downloads under a certain build number.
fields.summary: Add folders to bitbucket downloads

fields.summary: SSH Key "Added" Field Incorrect

fields.description:
bitbucket-pipelines.yml files which utilize anchors for steps fail validation. For new projects this can cause Bitbucket to not allow Pipelines to be enabled.

example:

{code}
#!yaml

image: java:8
pipelines:
  default:
    - step: &buildSnapshot
        name: Build snapshot
        caches:
          - gradle
        script:
          - bash ./gradlew clean
          - bash ./gradlew build
  branches:
    develop:
      - step: *buildSnapshot
...

{code}

This script fails with 'missing required property 'script' on the final -step line.

Once the anchor reference was removed, I was able to enable Pipelines for the project. Re-adding the anchor reference once pipelines was enabled resulted in a successful build, with all steps executed as expected.
fields.summary: Cannot enable Pipelines - validator incorrectly fails on anchor reference

fields.description:
Hi

I am getting the following error for the last few weeks. It is intermittent as it sometimes work, and other times don't. Currently I  am unable to trigger a build due to it which causes me serious pain.

Failed to connect to repository : Command "C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd\git.exe ls-remote -h https://bitbucket.org/containerchain/emptycontainerdepot.git HEAD" returned status code 128:\\
stdout:\\
stderr: remote: Too many invalid password attempts. Try logging in through the website with your password.\\
fatal: unable to access 'https://bitbucket.org/containerchain/emptycontainerdepot.git/': The requested URL returned error: 403

Regards
fields.summary: Jenkins integration error: Too Many failed password attempts

fields.description:
Seems I've used up all my trial minutes trying to use pipelines for the first time.

Here is my really simple pipeline yaml,

{code}
#!yaml

# This is a sample build configuration for JavaScript.
# Check our guides at https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/14UWN for more examples.
# Only use spaces to indent your .yml configuration.
# -----
# You can specify a custom docker image from Docker Hub as your build environment.
image: arm32v7/node:8.10.0

pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        caches:
          - node
        script: # Modify the commands below to build your repository.
          - npm install
          - npm run package
{code}

This is a somewhat complete project I suppose, it must compile binaries as node dependencies.

The two npm commands take about 5 minutes to run successfully on my local environment.  Not sure if that is what is hanging or if it really does take 20 minutes just to set up the build in Bitbucket.

Here is the log, I finally killed it after 20 minutes because there is no way this is useful to me if it takes that long just to setup the environment.

fields.description:
I added an inline comment and task to a recent PR, and it is being hidden by the code folding functionality. Only by expanding the code is the comment shown, and it further seems that there's a slight visual bug in the sidebar itself.

This affects both Chrome and Firefox.

*Update*

There is a bug as some users use New UI and Old UI. When a user comments from the Old Pull Request UI on a line which had no changes, the comment gets hidden when viewing from the New Pull Request UI. 

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Have another user comments on the Pull Request from the Old UI inline the diff that has no changes
# Another user view the PR from the New UI, the specific lines are hidden and thus the comments remains hidden. 
# The comments are visible in the activity tab (on the right side bar) but clicking on the link in the comments scrolls the page to the specific file. 
#* However the comment remains hidden. 


*Workaround*
# Expand the hidden lines by clicking the three dotted button and you'll see the comments. 
# Alternatively, you can disable the New Pull Request UI and enable the Old Pull Request UI in Bitbucket Labs as this issue is reproducible to the New Pull Request UI.
fields.summary: Pull request comment/task mistakenly hidden in code folding bar

fields.description:
Hello,

So I am using bitbucket api to get the diff of files in a PR. Somehow, its responding an empty string even though the PR has file changes. The issue seems to be reproducible, tried it in multiple repos from multiple accounts.

This is the command I am using to access this.

curl --user USERNAME:PASSWORD -s -XGET "https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/{OWNER}/{REPO_SLUG}/pullrequests/{PR_ID}/diff"

When I try this command, it works.

curl --user USERNAME:PASSWORD -s -XGET "https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/{OWNER}/{REPO_SLUG}/pullrequests/{PR_ID}/comments"

Can someone please help me here.?
fields.summary: bitbucket api /diff endpoint responding with empty string

fields.description:

At the very least, it should require privilege elevation / reconfirmation:

# Require a confirmation via a different channel (e.g.) e-mail

However, whenever I try to access a folder with 495 files, the working circle icon just spins.  It has been spinning for more than 20 minutes.  I get the same results in both IE and Chrome. fields.description:
In a .rst file of the wiki part of a repository:

{code}
H1
==
H2-is-missing
-------------
{code}

is wrongly only rendered as:

h1. H1
----
Looking for how to make the title appear, I found two workarounds:

* have two or more subsections, not just one:

{code}
H1
==
H2a-is-OK
---------
H2b-is-OK
---------
{code}

* have some contents above (a text or a transition is enough):

{code}
H1
==
----
H2-is-OK
--------
{code}

This issue can be directly experienced with the online editor.

Note: it may have some similarities with BCLOUD-14129.
fields.summary: reStructuredText: a unique subsection without previous contents is swallowed

fields.description:
I would like to suggest the possibility to add attributes for a branch, and send these attributes in the webhooks.

Such attributes would be configuration which is not of interest to check in, and only apply for a specific branch.

Example:

* DebugLevel = x
* TestA = enabled

These attributes would be sent in each webhook, and can be used by the ci machine to build/test/deploy the branch in a special way.

It is of course also possible to keep this information close to ci, but it is preferred to have possibility to add/remove/view attributes via the bitbucket gui.
fields.summary: Webhooks with branch attributes

fields.description: After an issue is created, when editing it and adding a comment. The content of this comment is empty on the webhooks body.

fields.description:
I have to manage a large number of pull requests across multiple repositories, and I often prioritise which PRs to work on based on the relative size of a PR - the larger the size of the PR, the longer it takes me on an exponential scale.

It would be very helpful if the number of affected files that is shown in the details view for a pull request is also shown as a column in the list of pull requests as well, so that I don't have to keep opening up individual PRs to see that information.

It would be even better if it was further broken down into counts for added, deleted, modified files as well.
fields.summary: Suggestion: Show number of affected files in list of open Pull Requests

fields.description:
Hi,

Currently when a default step is defined the same commit pushed to different branches triggers parallel pipeline execution (attached a screenshot, notice the times and the same commit hash).

In many cases (such as testing and linting) this is just a waste of compute time. But, since it is true that some Pipelines steps are for sure needed to be executed, even multiple times, on the same commit, I would like to suggest a new pipeline feature:

It would be really nice if there will be a 'non-repeatable' option of some sort which will indicate the a certain step does not need to be re-executed on the same commit if it already have.

Maybe something like this:

pipelines:\\
default:\\
- step:\\
options:\\
- non-repeatable    <--- this is the suggestion\\
caches:\\
- node\\
script:\\
- yarn install\\
- npm test
fields.summary: "non-repeatable" pipeline option

fields.description:
Infinite page refresh during create repository. The following message is displayed\\
"Please wait a moment while we create your repository". I have tried creating one more but its the same behaviour.
fields.summary: Create repository - "Please wait a moment while we create your repository"

fields.description:
According to the [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/notifications-for-bitbucket-pipelines-857053284.html], you can get emails about when you push and the pipeline fails, and/or for all failed pipelines in a repository.

But if {{develop}} fails, everybody should get an email. To do this, one would have to activate the latter option ("all failed pipelines in a repository").

However, when several people work on their own feature branches and cause failing pipeline builds on these branches, it makes no sense to spam everybody.

Therefore, as an additional option, please allow each team member to choose specific branches for which they want to receive build failure notifications.
fields.summary: Pipelines email notifications for specific failing branches

fields.description: The Coin3D project on Bitbucket owns 25 subrepos (SoQt, SoWin, Coin, ...). To improve the handling of issues and pull requests a common feed monitoring and bundling the activity in subrepositories would be desirable.

fields.description:
Original title "Improvements for code search"

Searching our repositories for something like "foo-bar" returned unexpected results because the "-" was removed and the search became "foo bar".  After playing around with my query for a bit I had to read to the very end of the documentation to understand what was going on.

A couple of suggestions:\\
Source code commonly has symbols in it.  It would make the search functionality vastly more useful if those symbols could be preserved and searched for.

If symbols are removed from a query, indicate in the results what the search became and link to the documentation about how searching works.  This would cut down on
fields.summary: Support "-" in code search | indicate if removed from query

fields.description: There are still some long standing builds stuck in "In progress" status due to a bug. There will be a script to remove builds with this status. These builds should not take up any minutes.

fields.description:
I develop code on weekends and evenings and then use it to perform tasks on my day job and at my university. To do this I download my scripts from the BitBucket website, as I can't install a Git client locally.

Nearly every time I do this I first accidentally click the Clone in Sourcetree button, because it uses the widely accepted Download icon. Would it be possible to use another icon for Clone than the Download icon? Perhaps something similar to [FontAwesome's Clone |https://fontawesome.com/icons/clone%3Fstyle%3Dregular]icon could be used?
fields.summary: Download icon used for cloning

Intermittently, at the start of a pipelines build, it would fail with the following error. Re-running the build would be successful. Sometimes re-running would also produce the same error.

Error : rpc error: code = Canceled desc = context canceled
fields.summary: Pipelines fail with 'RPC error' at start of the build.

fields.description: The current bitbucket diff APIs do not handle move/renames in a smart manner. If I run {{git diff}} on the command line I get information as far as a file being renamed and similarity score. Bitbucket APIs return two separate diffs, an add and a delete, even if the contents are unchanged. In addition, this functionality seems to already be available for the actual bitbucket UI (eg: https://blog.bitbucket.org/2016/04/14/updated-diff-view-for-moved-or-renamed-files/), but not to the API. This makes it difficult for an integrating application to get an idea of the diff that an end-user is seeing without doing all of the diffing logic themselves.
fields.summary: Include rename/move information if diffs served by API

fields.description:
The Pipelines dashboard page does not update with new pipeline runs.

Steps to reproduce:

* Navigate to Pipelines in a repo.
* Click on a specific Pipeline run.
* Click on Pipelines link in the breadcrumbs to go to the list of pipeline runs.
* The list of pipelines runs does not show new pipelines, and still shows all runs as the same Status as before (ie In Progress, even though some have finished already).

Refreshing the page of course works around the problem, but is annoying.
fields.summary: Pipelines list doesn't auto-update when navigating via breadcrumb
Node Docker Container Cannot Run Yarn

fields.description:
This error is being caused by this bitbucket-pipelines.yml, which passes validation:

{code}
#!yaml

# Template: https://bitbucket.org/generator-vet-angular/app/templates/partials/bitbucket-pipelines/component.ejs

pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: Init Test Deployment
        image: realguess/jq
        script:
          - export THIS_VERSION=$(jq --raw-output ".version" package.json)

    - step:
        name: Build and Deploy to Verdaccio Test
        image: node:8
        deployment: test
        caches:
          - node
        script:
          # Build
          - yarn build:sb

          # Publish
          - mv .npmrc_config .npmrc
          - yarn publish --no-git-tag-version --new-version $THIS_VERSION-beta.$BITBUCKET_BUILD_NUMBER

  branches:
    master:
      - step:
          name: Init Prod Deployment
          image: realguess/jq
          script:
            - export THIS_VERSION=$(jq --raw-output ".version" package.json)

      - step:
          name: Build and Deploy to Verdaccio Production
          image: node:8
          deployment: production
          script:
            - yarn build:prod
            - mv .npmrc_config .npmrc
            - yarn publish --no-git-tag-version --new-version $THIS_VERSION

{code}
fields.summary: retrofit2.adapter.rxjava.HttpException: HTTP 409 Conflict (error key='result-service.step.conflict')

fields.description:
We have numerous pipelines setup and they all randomly fail when attempting to connect to resources over TLS. The failure rate is usually low but recently we are seeing the same pipelines fail repeatedly over the course of 20 mins completely blocking our ability to deploy.

More than likely you have XX number of VM's in your infrastructure that our docker containers randomly land on that have out-of-date packages or don't have apt-transport-https installed or some other TLS related issue.

Please see the logs for these pipelines:

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-user-asset-service-database/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/68

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-user-asset-service-database/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/69

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-user-asset-service-database/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/70

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-user-asset-service-database/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/71

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-user-asset-service-database/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/72

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-user-asset-service-database/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/73

https://bitbucket.org/buildasign/designer-kubernetes/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/398

Keep me apprised of your findings.
fields.summary: Bitbucket pipelines randomly fail when attempting to connect over TLS

fields.description:
This is almost entirely a *frivolous* feature request, and probably isn't worth that much effort. However, I thought it might be useful, so I thought I'd mention it.

I was scanning through diffs and blame files, trying to find a particular bit of code. The file in question, unfortunately, is sort of long.

So I was thinking: wouldn't it be nice if you could view the source, and if you held down the Ctrl key and moved the mouse zoom wheel, you went to earlier or later versions? (Presumably without the Ctrl key down should just scroll through the code as usual).

I'm sure this is harder than it seems, as you'd have to somehow keep aligned where you are in the code. Still, I can imagine situations in which it, or something like it, might be useful.

In general, I'm pretty happy with the product. At the moment, I'm mostly using the CLI tools, but may end up using the website more.

Josh
fields.summary: (feature request) mouse wheel version view

fields.description:
I have a docker pipelines script that ends with

{code}
- docker login --username $DOCKER_HUB_USERNAME --password $DOCKER_HUB_PASSWORD <our-private-repo>
- docker push $IMAGE
{code}

However, it looks like docker pushes images that are already present in the repository. I get the following output. This takes quite a bit of time as these layers are large.

{code}
b92ae2c28af1: Preparing
7bb9bf8c293d: Preparing
2939806abd05: Preparing
eb84ae861586: Preparing
227d94b074c0: Preparing
066828d986f0: Preparing
daa6e91e491c: Preparing
6b60013e5875: Preparing
d6335a641f5e: Preparing
5c33df241050: Preparing
ffc4c11463ee: Preparing
daa6e91e491c: Waiting
6b60013e5875: Waiting
d6335a641f5e: Waiting
066828d986f0: Waiting
ffc4c11463ee: Waiting
7bb9bf8c293d: Pushed
b92ae2c28af1: Pushed
eb84ae861586: Pushed
daa6e91e491c: Pushed
066828d986f0: Pushed
227d94b074c0: Pushed
5c33df241050: Pushed
d6335a641f5e: Pushed
ffc4c11463ee: Pushed
2939806abd05: Pushed
6b60013e5875: Pushed
{code}

When I do the exact same command on my own machine (Docker version 17.12.0-ce, build c97c6d6) I get the following (i.e. only the newly built last layer is actually being pushed. The id:s of the previous layers are the same for each build, but somehow the pipelines docker push does not recognize that the layers have already been pushed (by a previous build).

{code}
3133fd13fb37: Pushed
7bb9bf8c293d: Layer already exists
2939806abd05: Layer already exists
eb84ae861586: Layer already exists
227d94b074c0: Layer already exists
066828d986f0: Layer already exists
daa6e91e491c: Layer already exists
6b60013e5875: Layer already exists
d6335a641f5e: Layer already exists
5c33df241050: Layer already exists
ffc4c11463ee: Layer already exists
{code}

Our repository is using the {{registry:2}} image of the docker registry.
fields.summary: docker push to private repository pushes already pushed layers

fields.description:
I wanted to break my pipelines into steps (including parallel) but each step runs separately and env variables are not shared between them, so 3 steps that configure them has to be repeated for each step right now.

I'd like to have a way to specify that i want to keep env variables from previous step just like we keep files using "artifacts".
fields.summary: Ability to pass environment variables to later steps

fields.description:
Summary: *using the Docker API for creating containers is not possible, which prevents us from moving our builds to Bitbucket Pipelines (hence _blocker_). An error occurs in the authorization plugin.*

As discussed [here|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/create-continer-authorization-denied-by-plugin-pipelines-Command/qaq-p/731364].

Following minimal test in Pipelines configuration ({{bitbucket-pipelines.yml}}):

{code}
#!yaml
script:
  ...
  - "curl -X POST http://localhost:2375/containers/create -d '{\"image\":\"hello-world\", \"name\":\"hello_2\"}' -H 'Content-Type: application/json'"
{code}

That leads to the following error when you look under the {{docker}} tab:

{code}
2018/03/14 17:45:11 http: panic serving @: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
goroutine 5 [running]:
net/http.(*conn).serve.func1(0xc42008c8c0)
    /usr/local/go/src/net/http/server.go:1697 +0xd0
panic(0x6a5000, 0x880800)
    /usr/local/go/src/runtime/panic.go:491 +0x283
bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/pkg/authz/request.(*ContainerCreateBodyAuthorizer).Authz(0xc4200e2300, 0xc420348090, 0x29, 0x2a, 0x1)
    /go/src/bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/pkg/authz/request/body_authorizer.go:25 +0xa6
bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/pkg/authz/request.(*Authorizer).Authz(0xc4200e2320, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0xc420352028, 0x4, 0xc420350020, 0x12, 0xc420348090, ...)
    /go/src/bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/pkg/authz/request/authorizer.go:31 +0xd5
bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/pkg/authz/plugin.(*AuthzPlugin).AuthZReq(0xc4200e3240, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0xc420352028, 0x4, 0xc420350020, 0x12, 0xc420348090, ...)
    /go/src/bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/pkg/authz/plugin/authz_plugin.go:90 +0x100
bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/vendor/github.com/docker/go-plugins-helpers/authorization.(*Handler).initMux.func1(0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0xc420352028, 0x4, 0xc420350020, 0x12, 0xc420348090, 0x29, ...)
    /go/src/bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/vendor/github.com/docker/go-plugins-helpers/authorization/api.go:118 +0xa0
bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/vendor/github.com/docker/go-plugins-helpers/authorization.(*Handler).handle.func1(0x8572c0, 0xc42035a000, 0xc420346000)
    /go/src/bitbucket.com/bitbucketci/docker/vendor/github.com/docker/go-plugins-helpers/authorization/api.go:139 +0x144
net/http.HandlerFunc.ServeHTTP(0xc420010af0, 0x8572c0, 0xc42035a000, 0xc420346000)
    /usr/local/go/src/net/http/server.go:1918 +0x44
net/http.(*ServeMux).ServeHTTP(0xc42007af30, 0x8572c0, 0xc42035a000, 0xc420346000)
    /usr/local/go/src/net/http/server.go:2254 +0x130
net/http.serverHandler.ServeHTTP(0xc420089380, 0x8572c0, 0xc42035a000, 0xc420346000)
    /usr/local/go/src/net/http/server.go:2619 +0xb4
net/http.(*conn).serve(0xc42008c8c0, 0x8577c0, 0xc42005c340)
    /usr/local/go/src/net/http/server.go:1801 +0x71d
created by net/http.(*Server).Serve
    /usr/local/go/src/net/http/server.go:2720 +0x288
time="2018-03-14T17:45:11.730269200Z" level=warning msg="Unable to connect to plugin: /run/docker/plugins/pipelines.sock/AuthZPlugin.AuthZReq: Post http://%2Frun%2Fdocker%2Fplugins%2Fpipelines.sock/AuthZPlugin.AuthZReq: EOF, retrying in 1s"
time="2018-03-14T17:45:12Z" level=info msg="Pipelines plugin request authorization." allowed=false method= plugin=pipelines uri=
time="2018-03-14T17:45:12.731391033Z" level=error msg="AuthZRequest for POST /containers/create returned error: plugin pipelines failed with error: AuthZPlugin.AuthZReq: EOF\n{\"Allow\":false,\"Msg\":\"Command not supported.\"}\n"
time="2018-03-14T17:45:12.731446791Z" level=error msg="Handler for POST /containers/create returned error: plugin pipelines failed with error: AuthZPlugin.AuthZReq: EOF\n{\"Allow\":false,\"Msg\":\"Command not supported.\"}\n"
{code}

fields.description:
Does the current test result "parser" handle .net core  XUnit.net "trx" format? If not is there a plan to add such capability?

I have attempted to use a .net core logger for xunit and nunit as well that are outlined here: https://github.com/Faizan2304/LoggerExtensions

Unfortunately they did not work in Bitbucket pipelines.

Any help or direction would be appreciated.

Here is an example of the Nunit output (which appeared close to what is acceptable?):

fields.summary: Pipeline XUnit.net Test Results

fields.description: I ([Matt Angus|https://bitbucket.org/mattangus/]) have access to someones private repositories ([Matthew Angus|https://bitbucket.org/Matt-Angus/]) with the same name.
fields.summary: Access to another users private repository.

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

# generate ssh key on your computer and add that key to your account with email1
# set in git config --local(or --global) user.email "email2"
# try to commit something. You will see that email2 user has made commit. But ssh was attached to email1 account.
fields.summary: ssh bug

fields.description:
Imagine the following scenario:

* In the foobar project there is a badger repository
* In the foobar project there is also a badger-fork repository that forks the badger repository
* As an end-user I fork the badger-fork repository and work on some changes
* I want to create a PR, but the target repository should be the badger project, not badger-fork

Currently the Bitbucket UI offers badger-fork over other personal repositories, but the badger repository itself is hidden usually somewhere in the middle of the repository list. It would be great if Bitbucket would offer first the repositories that are on a "fork-chain" before offering any personal repositories as destinations.
fields.summary: Improve PR destination suggestions to prefer repository fork over personal forks

fields.description:
Inviting user with external email causes error.
